text:
Tiny documentation example fix :)

Django 1.5 allows apps to change the default user model - so `get_user_model()` should be called rather than using User directly.
title: Django example should use get_user_model(), rather than User as of 1.5
Django example should use get_user_model(), rather than User as of 1.5

text:
Tiny documentation example fix :)

Django 1.5 allows apps to change the default user model - so `get_user_model()` should be called rather than using User directly.
title: Django example should use get_user_model(), rather than User as of 1.5

text: Looks good! Is the get_user_model valid prior to django 1.5 too?
It's not. I'd keep the original example as calling explicitly `User` class isn't really harmful. It's an example anyway, so it doesn't need to be overly complicated.
I had some notion of it being backported but I don't think that's the case actually - sticking with `User` makes sense.

Django example should use get_user_model(), rather than User as of 1.5

Django 1.5 allows apps to change the default user model - so
get_user_model() should be called rather than using User directly.
